title: What is the highest atomic number of any element, and what is that element called? - Quora

response.answer_text: Radium has highest atomic mass Ra Symbol: Radium Atomic Number: 88 Atomic Weight: 226.0254 Element Classification: Alkaline-earth Metal Discovered By: Pierre and Marie Curie-Sklodowska Discovery Date: 1898 (France/Poland) Name Origin: Latin: radius (ray). Density (g/cc): (5.5) Melting Point (K): 973 Boiling Point (K): 1413 Appearance: Silvery white radioactive element Atomic Radius (pm): n/a Atomic Volume (cc/mol): 45.0 Covalent Radius (pm): n/a Ionic Radius: 143 (+2e) Specific Heat (@20°C J/g mol): 0.120 Fusion Heat (kJ/mol): (9.6) Evaporation Heat (kJ/mol): (113) Thermal Conductivity (@25°C W/m K): Debye Temperature (K): n/a Pauling Negativity Number: 0.9 First Ionizing Energy (kJ/mol): 509.0 Oxidation States: 2 Electronic Configuration: [Rn] 7s[2] Lattice Structure: n/a Lattice Constant (Å): n/a Lattice C/A Ratio: n/a

Ununoctium is the systematic element name given to #118, the highest-Z element yet created. (Z is the usual symbol for the atomic number.) It follows the IUPAC rule that a new element, until a formal name is decided upon, is named from the digits of its atomic number. 'Un' is used for the digit 1; 'bi' for 2; 'tri' for 3; 'quad' for 4; 'pent' for 5; 'hex' for 6; 'sept' for 7; 'oct' for 8; 'enn' for 9; 'nil' for 0. The symbol for the element is the initials of the three syllables. Since #118 has two 1s and an 8, its provisional name is un + un + oct + the suffix -ium, or ununoctium, with the symbol Uuo. #109 was called unnilennium (Une) before it was named meitnerium; #124 would have the provisional name of unbiquadium (Ubq). edited to add: Ununoctium was formally named oganesson in November 2016, honoring the nuclear physicist Yuri Oganessian who has been a leading figure in the synthesis of the later superheavy elements.
